cultural_namechanging_description: Using a double name in science is demanding in Germany
cultural_namechanging_solution_descripti: Using different names in science than in my private life.
work_equality: Well, the idea that there is equality is not true, specifically when it comes to a career.  At all levels of my career there were obstacles for me as a women in science. When I was studying there was still the prejudice about a women studying in computer science, that they might not be capable, that a computer scientist cannot be pretty and clever, ... In my studies it was clearly mentioned by male students that they would never accept a women as a boss (1989). This might have changed but is was the mindset of that time. In all levels of my career I was the only women. When I had success it was then sometimes mentioned that it was because I was a women. Womens' topics and talking about equality was for decades something that women - such as me - were fighting for - it took until around 2020 when more men were stepping in and understanding equality as a responsibility for all genders. I have lost 20% of my intellectual potential and time because I was a women, because I had to show more to get the same positions, because I had to spend time in committee meetings when others made their careers, because I was not in the right boys networks, ... That is a loss not only for me but also a loss for a society as this did not happen to me but to many women.
label: Prejudice
work_equality_solution: Never give up, connect in women networks, reveal the inequality in all places and situations I see it, mentor young women, give women a voice, make institutions change and implement gender equality plans. ... keep moving forward.
work_unsupported: For too many years I felt it was alway me mentioning to respect and be aware of inequality. For a decade I mentioned it in so many meeting, that it is not only Mitarbeiter but also Mitarbeiterin, that it is not man month but person months and so on.  Women were responsible for gender quality. Women who were acting to make change got a negative image as "Emanze" (feminist). The universities took and my institute took a long time to finally implement better rules for gender quality. Only in 2021 we see some gender equality plan  now on the university level, on the level of European Projects and so on. But is was a very long and low process.
work_unsupported_solution: Sticking to it, meeting and exchanging with other women, building networks of women. Promoting young women and giving them the support I never had.
work_collaborations: As I was often the only one, the rules on the table were that of men. But at the same time when I behave - as aggressively - as them i was the "bitch", I was difficult, I  was having "hair on teeth".  One not only had to work on one's own career but also had to navigate this with competing men who played not always fair.
work_collaborations_solution: Coaching, Courses, Networking. That has helped a lot.
technical_appreciation: It is a subtile process. Men know men, they cite men, the propose men for awards, they chose men for their team, the mentor men, they write better letters of recommendations for men. So the appreciation is constantly given more to men and than to women.
technical_appreciation_solution:
When I was studying I thought it is all about competence. Only after time I found out about the other factors of networking and so on. 
As a doctoral student I did not have the problem so much as I was quite successful.
In the years as professor it was more difficult as I was now competing for resources, H-Index, Grants and so on. It took my years to get a standing there. 
But there were also  two male mentors who helped.
technical_researcher_solution: Observing it, trying to understand the game, be prepared and taking opportunities next time, next meeting ....

cultural_others_description: Different perspective on working women between south and north parts of Germany.
work_equality: Why, you are never equal! E.g. no chances to get a W3 position. No chances to get positions in University politics, as long as an old man is available for the same job. etc. There is no equality at University.
label: Politics
work_unsupported: During my time of qualification, there was no support for equality.
work_collaborations: Often ignored, best be loud and present. Another working way would be: forget to be the idea giver. Introduce your ideas to the leading men at the place and let them sell them as their own. At least then you can start to work constructively.
technical_appreciation: no additional comments - the yes said all.
technical_researcher: sure. Who has not? And moreover, there are only very few networking women. However, almost all successful men are networking. In contrast: females who have gained a position are often eager to bite other woman away. Sad but true.

work_country2: USA (only fo one term as an exchange Scientist)

work_unsupported: No full time jobs for women, only for male phd students
technical_publications_solution: Private meetings to discuss problems with boss

cultural_others_description:
1. Missing supervision,
2. Missing interculturality, internationality,
3. Missing exchange in the group, discipline and world wide
cultural_others_solution_description:
1. Not really - asking advanced researcher
2. Participating in events outside my group
3. Finding other platforms of exchange
work_equality: Participating at a event as "statutory woman"
label: Undermining
work_equality_solution:
Deciding on my own if I -want- to participate in the event.
Taking the chance anyway.

cultural_others_description:
Safety at ways to work or from work, safety at conference ways to the hotel.
Different types of communication between me and my (almost all) male peers.
cultural_others_solution_description:
On business trips, I found nice colleagues to walk me to the hotel. At the university, I found a colleague who also preferred to not walk alone to the parking area at night after work. As a professor, I made the rule that women are always allowed to take a taxi at night and book the conference hotel.
There is an excellent course on communication differences by Peter Modler.
work_equality: Regarding the performance and achievements, I should have been more recognized than I was.  Colleagues from other countries were really surprised about that.
label: Expertise_perception
work_unsupported: I have only be supported by some nice colleagues from Germany and other countries. My supervisor and the official institutions did not support me -- to use friendly words.
work_unsupported_solution: One important measure was to change the university. The other was to not care and simply do research.
technical_researcher: Yes, it decreased though in the last years.

scientific_field: IT (HCI, which is at the border of IT)

technical_researcher_solution: Initiative of university to prefer hiring females/members of underrepresented or minority groups in case of equal qualification

technical_publications: "struggle" with seniors that had to be put in author list. However, it was not a matter of gender more of seniority and prestige. some disiciplines are more title and prestige oriented than others...

cultural_others_description: Japanese company, because of parental leave no bonus payment/salary increase agreed by the company mangement, for time before parental leave, although my boss fighted for that.
cultural_others_solution_description: My boss arranged another additional payment, which he could decide on by himself. However, this is not relevant for the pension in contrast to the bonus payment/salary increase.
work_equality:
The feeling, not being taken seriously
- payment
- prejudices
- verbal offensive
- not taken into account, that being parents involve lot of work. This surely also holds for fathers, however fathers only a few years ago started to be more present.
label: Prejudice Salary_expectation/ family_planningissues related to family planningchildcare/ Male_communication
work_unsupported:
- For many "minor" things, i never asked for support, except of my family
- no real dual career support
- awareness of problems and support for having a family and plan a scientific career at the same time
work_unsupported_solution:
I had children only after my PhD. 
I renounced a pure academic career.
I did work part-time, although it was not helpful for the career.
work_collaborations:
-arrogance, despite equal or minor competence
- being made insecure
- impudence
work_collaborations_solution: Searching working groups, where the athmosphere is convenient, and quit the others as soon as possible.
technical_ideasharing:
This also happens, because some women do not take part in discussions, or men just start talking, while women are waiting to be next.
However, younger women sometimes seem to be more present. And this also heavily depends on the character.

cultural_clothing_description: Once "we" had a woman in a Niqab in an oral exam - the identification process was hard for the stuff, because there was no woman to check, that's why I came into play. I checked her, but it was strange to do it on a public toilet, because there are not enough non windowed rooms at the university I came from.
cultural_clothing_solution_description: Once "we" had a woman in a Niqab in an oral exam - the identification process was hard for the stuff, because there was no woman to check, that's why I came into play. I checked her, but it was strange to do it on a public toilet, because there are not enough non windowed rooms at the university I came from.
cultural_namechanging_description: I'm not sure, if this fit's but we are always in trouble with students from other countries, who do have trouble naming us and naming themselves in the European way.
work_equality: An old professor told me not to wear skirts, because women don't fit in computer science.
label: Conventions
work_equality_solution: I talked with friends about my feelings and tried to not speak to that professor again.
work_collaborations: Sometimes and only sometimes men do not accept me. It happened once because of the cultural background and sometimes without a real reason, maybe because I was the only woman, maybe because I had other ideas in group work. I really don't like these jokes about women and technology, which are used to lough about me and other female students.
work_collaborations_solution: When circumstances allow, I talk to supervisors or the project leader. When I was a student, I once talked to the course supervisors. It didn't really help, but I learned to ignore those persons.
technical_ideasharing: Every week in the project meetings, we have some "alpha men" in our group, who like to talk a lot and they don't pay any attention to my try to speak.
technical_publications:
Oh yes. I once worked with a male professor, who forced us to give him the first authorship, what we did.
In my case, men would always like to write their names on it because they have contributed something. And that's despite the fact that some of them have previously claimed that my subject area is "soft" and uninteresting. But when they realise that the field does lead to publications, they think they belong on the paper because they were there at a meeting and gave their opinion.
technical_publications_solution: I have a great supervisor (male) and a female mentor, who help me to stay confident.
technical_researcher: As already said in the research project I'm working on are some loud and confident male persons, they tend to get priority in the meetings, because they argue loud and often about their needs.
technical_researcher_solution: I need to schedule extra meetings with some partners for my work.

cultural_religion_description: One of my colleagues was a satanist and I am wearing a silver cross around the neck.
cultural_religion_solution_description: We did not talk about religion. I had to quit the job anyway as my bosses had problems with my high qualification. They were making jokes about people from academics who did not get a professor position and then are worthless.
cultural_clothing_description: I was professor, and one of my assistants was telling everyone, including our students, that she would never wear such clothes as I do. (pinstripe trousers and jacket).
cultural_clothing_solution_description: She lost the job. Joke. No, we had a lot of further problems with each other. So, I did not continue her contract which was limited anyway.
cultural_infrastructure_description:
I got a very slow computer with loud keyboard and very small disk space. I was sitting in the same room with my boss. As he said he can not work while I type, he forbade me to type while he is in the office. So, then I started work earlier in the morning to type before he arrives. During his presence, I did not type but read instead. As I started to work early, I thought at first I can go home early. But then he complained that I am lazy and go home so early. So, I came early and stayed as long as before. Instead, I made a longer break around noon, writing private emails. Then, he started telling everyone that during the day, I do not productive work at all. Either I read or I write private emails. He never sees me working. (Because I did the writing in the morning, before he came!) 
The other problem with the disk space: I worked on course material for several weeks. When they were done,  I sent them to my boss by email. Then, I had the file twice: as file and in the emails. To save space, I deleted the email. Then, the disk space still was not sufficient, so I moved the course material to a shared folder in the network. On a day when I was not in the office, my boss deleted this file because he said he did not know what it was and assumed it was useless. As I had sent hom the course by email, I asked him to look for the email and restore the course material, but he did not do it. I asked several times, then I had to understand that my course was lost.
cultural_infrastructure_solution_descrip: I lost the job. Not because of the infrastructure, but because of my notorious laziness. I was taken away most of my tasks when people heard that I studied English and French, notthing technical. I did not hear it before I left. In fact, I studied Physics and Engineering (two diplomas). So, that was probably the root cause of the problems. I had also further problems like that I was taken for a secretary, so everyone expected my to have access to my bosses calendar. As I had not, they thought I had instruction to give them no information. Etc etc. There were a lot of complaints about my work because they expected me to be a secretary what I was not.
work_equality: Usually, it was assumed that I have not studied and have no work experience. I was regularly told to that "for being sure" they assume I have no relevant work experience. So, I was considered a job beginner at every job. When a new male colleague came, he was welcomed as "one man more in the team" and given real work from the beginning. I was told they have no time for explaining me their work I shall sit and read something and not keep others from working. So, the treatment was different from the beginning., I had different tasks and when I complained, they again explained me the difference between men and women. Men are colleagues, women are constant trainees.
label: Prejudice/Undermining
work_collaborations: As long as I was young and asking only questions, it was OK for them. Men like to explain things to women and feel superior. But when I started having work experience and my own opinion, there was a lot of resistance against working with me.
technical_ideasharing: I was for instance recommended to not present my results in the group and at conferences because it was not perfect. Men can present non-perfect results, but I would not stand the critics I would get. So, to protect my feelings, I was not allowed to present my results although I wanted.
technical_appreciation:
The results of men are real results, my results were often not believed to be mine. For instance, I was told they were too good, they must stem from someone else with more competence than I can have. 
This happend the stronger, the more qualified I was. I suppose it was because my results improved, so the difference between what they expect from a woman and of what I deliver was larger.
technical_publications:
We had a male colleague who squeezed into the author list although he had not worked on the paper at all. He just allowed his (female) PhD student to publish it.
I had also problems publishing, was not always allowed to publish my results.
technical_researcher: Yes, all the time. People say it is eithcal to give them priority. They need unlimited jobs and high salaries to nourish their familiy and build a house. I as a woman can become a housewife. So, I need no job at all, can do research at my kitchen table.

cultural_clothing_description: It is always a burden to decide about clothing. In an all-male culture, you cannot follow the dress code of men, esp. if it is (like in Computer Science) very casual. This again leads to a distinction between the male crowd and the female outstander. It is easier with formal dress code.
cultural_clothing_solution_description: Prefer formal clothing, if in doubt. No Skin.
cultural_infrastructure_description: Deserted, dark buildings and paths in the evenings and weekends, not feeling safe. Desks to high. Lavs in remote places of the building. Large rooms without mics.
cultural_others_description: Has to comply to one of two stereotypes: 1) aggressive, career oriented, expensive clothing, noisy and disliked by everyone, or 2) nice, pretty, quiet, hard working, liked by everyone, but never advance in your career.
label: Salary_Expectation/Men_promote_men
work_collaborations: Do not take serious. Think that stop to work after marriage / children. Continue work in pubs and at sports events where women are not present. Think that your task is to serve them. Take your results and claim for themselves.

cultural_others_solution_description: I tell people how to speak / spell my name
technical_others: Organisational aspects in a collaborative project fall to me when I am the only woman on the team. It is also hard to be aggressive and assertive when working with an all-male team. I feel like I also have to push harder to get the same level of support in a collaborative project in comparison to a male colleague.
technical_others_solution: I ask other male colleagues / supervisor to help with pushing other male colleagues in a collaborative setting.

cultural_clothing_description: I was expected to dress more formal than my male colleagues
cultural_clothing_solution_description: I ignored it and continued to wear what I like
work_collaborations: Older people at the institute made very misogynist comments or were commenting on my outfits when they thought they were nice (although I had no contact with these people otherwise); some collaborators took my male students more serious than me, although I was the project leader; I was told to smile more after a talk instead of any scientific input; I needed to tell people off for flirting instead of working with me.
work_collaborations_solution: I tried not to interact with these people
work_infrastructure: There was only one female bathroom with one toilet on my floor; I often had to go several floors down if someone else was using it, which was more often than not with four female secretaries, one other female student and me sharing this one bathroom. The male bathroom right next to it had 4 cubicles.
technical_appreciation: Sometimes, I felt like I am not even seen as part of the project, although I was the key initiator. Male researchers with equally or less successful PhDs were called genius and highly valuable etc., I was just that one woman on the team.
technical_appreciation_solution: I am not working there any longer ;)
technical_researcher: Who was invited to give talks often was a decision based on someone knew a guy even though there were more successful women who could have talked about the same thing
technical_others: Not sure whether this is of interest but I was explicitly mentioned in the realm of research projects I wasn't part of, just so the project looked more diverse. Me explicitly saying that I don't want this was just ignored.

work_unsupported: many social aspects are structured around going out late at night with in most cases just men. These are rather subtle things. but collaborations are best with people one likes to hang out with have fun and in most cases beers. Despite this being unproblematic for myself I see lots of my female colleagues with different cultural or personal backgrounds not participating in these activities which ultimately lead to less equality.

work_equality: the equal opportunities officer himself uses sexist slides in his lecture...
label: Male_communication
work_collaborations: lack of understanding / refusal to 'gender' (use male and female form for occupations words etc. as opposed to only using the male form in writing)
work_collaborations_solution: insisting to do that in written form and lead discussions about it
